items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tech Design Comics and Artificial Intelligence Money
items.abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Thursday, selections include Internet technologies spreading into more industries, which Web sites share what information and the latest iPhone bug.

items.title: Fresh Insights Where Decay Meets Architecture
items.abstract: Thom Andersen’s film “Reconversão,” coming to the Museum of the Moving Image’s First Look series, examines buildings by the Portuguese architect Eduardo Souto de Moura.

items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Bitter Debate Over Nuclear Power Simmers in Rural South Korea
items.abstract: In 2010, three villages agreed to give up their land to make room for a power plant, plunging the area into a battle over whether the plant would be a savior or a death knell.

items.title: Intimate, Haunting Portraits of New York City Youth
items.abstract: The photographer (and model) Ethan James Green finds many of the subjects in his ongoing series of creatives on social media.

items.title: City’s Delayed Traffic Study to Guide Regulation of Uber Vehicles
items.abstract: The study, which was originally due at the end of November, aimed to assess the ride-hailing service’s effects on traffic congestion in Manhattan.

items.title: New York City Announces Deal on Carriage Horses in Central Park
items.abstract: The Central Park horse carriage industry would be significantly reduced and pedicabs would be prohibited from operating below 85th Street under a deal announced late Sunday by the de Blasio administration.

items.title: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
items.abstract: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: The Army, in Need of Recruits, Turns Focus to Liberal-Leaning Cities
items.abstract: Too few recruits are signing up from cities like Chicago and Seattle, so the Army is trying to frame enlistment as a patriotic detour.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Judge Blocks New York City Law Aimed at Curbing Airbnb Rentals
items.abstract: The law was intended to prevent apartments from being used as illegal hotels. The decision could aid home-sharing services’ fights in other cities.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: What if Cities Are No Longer the Land of Opportunity for Low-Skilled Workers?
items.abstract: Dense cities have long promised higher wages, but now that is primarily true for workers with more education, a new analysis finds.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
items.abstract: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

items.title: A Rising Designer Brings Hip-Hop to Homeware
items.abstract: Sean Brown is the creative force behind Curves, a home décor brand inspired by African American pop culture. “I always aim to celebrate Blackness,” he said.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

items.title: ‘Attempted Security Threat’ Disables Software at Some New York Schools
items.abstract: The outage in a platform used by teachers and students has caused another disruption for a system that has had its share amid the pandemic.
keywords: Goldstein, Leon M, High School for the Sciences (Brooklyn, NY)
